we could only wish pakistani president zardari good luck as he navigates the stormy seas of pakistani politics.

but the next president of the philippines faces even more mind-boggling problems than what mr zardari has to put up w/ today.

the philippines, whence came people power, embarks on what the filipino people hope to be a watershed, crossroads even this year. yet, certain constraints that may prevent the may 2010 presidential elections from being so--a pivotal, epochal, cathartic event--loom in the horizon.

for one, the quality of the character of the top 5 aspirants leaves much to be desired. only two are decidedly anti-gloria macapagal arroyo, the current malacanang palace (rp's white house) tenant, who's widely detested by most filipinos for her misgovernance, corruption and warlordism.

sen. benigno cojauangco aquino iii (bca iii), son of the late president corazon cojaungco aquino--the principal beneficiary of the 1986 philippines people power revolution--touts himself as being anti-arroyo. and so does former president joseph estrada, whom arroyo deposed in a virtual coup d' etat in january 2001. on the other end, administration candidate g. teodoro, real estate tycoon turned consummate "trapo" (traditional politician)sen. manuel villar and sen. richard gordon are widely seen as veritable arroyo clones, a baggage too heay for them to carry.

yet for all the good things that accrued to the cojuangco/aquino clans on account of people power, nothing has been done by them--not by corazon cojuangco aquino even before she succumbed to cancer of the colon, or even bca iii himself--to do right by, or make amends to, the real author of the 1986 philippines people power revolution philosophical construct for 24 years now. the author, a writer-journalist, still wallows in abject poverty &, w/c is even worse, is continuously devoured by the revolution he had helped make.

this deliberate, malicious neglect of the people power author probably helps explain why the philippines has been laboring under a curse for about the same length of tiume now, close to a quarter of a century. even bca iii's running mate, sen. manuel roxas ii, in one of his press conferences a few years back in the senate press office, had been boorish in fielding the pointed but decent questions of the people power author, who was also then a senate beat reporter; worse, one roxas's bodyguard thug, piqued by the poor chap's brave questioning of his boss, even intentionally elbowed the newsman-author in the face.

finally, none of the presidential wannabes has learned one of the major lessons in arroyo's 2001 power grab, that is, a conniving philippine supreme court can unseat a legitimately, honestly, & freely elected philippine president, & in turn, install a usurper as an ersatz malacanang tenant. that is even worse a gordian knot than zardari's non-constitutional woes.

Mr. Goel,

Grrrrrrrrrrrrrrr.

(Also, thank you for your response. I suppose I'll just have to fade off into that Valhalla of the crotchety purists...)
I'm waiting for one that works on brainwaves

I think Netflix may have unwittingly given new life to Blockbuster.  Netflix may be prevented from getting the new movies for a month, Blockbuster has no such restriction.  Time will tell if people will be willing to wait one month for the newest releases and either buy or rent them from another source.

Anticipation is building for the Apple announcement because Steve Jobs does "insanely great" like nobody else.  How about a 10" multi-touch tablet, wifi for streaming media (movies, newspapers, ebooks) and VOIP phone with forward-facing webcam for teleconferencing for $500, or for $200 with optional 3G+telephone service (and subsidy) from Verizon?  Think: color Kindle on steroids with a ringtone?  Naw, probably too pedestrian and predictable to satisfy Jobs.
I am my own media conglomerate.

Same in France where I used to work for a company developing big project in Renewable Energy.The whole problem is that a government own infracstruture needs to be put at the disposition to free market. In France one big state own company  EDF owns the power line, and is obstructing independant energby producers to use its power line or to even buy their electricity. Delivery is the key to the problem.

In a former career, I helped write a contract for electricity delivered to certain locations. Delivery is the key. Most of the transmission is built and owned to deliver power and is locked in to its existing owners. Most of what Enron did wrong was to try to sell power that couldn't be delivered - thank you sir, can I have another! [movie reference to Animal House].
But the dollars are astounding. My last contract was for three quarters of a billion dollars just for a minor fraction of the required power in one state.

The portability issue is not thinness; it's weight. The virtue of a paperback book is that it's lighter not that it's thinner than a hardback. Ultimately nobody in their right mind cares if a laptop is one inch thick or one half inch.

Size matters - just not this kind of size.

Having just bought a Samsung Blu-Ray DVD play just because it streams NetFlix to my TV set, [I have never, and probably will never, watch a Blu-Ray DVD as long as regular DVDs are available], I could care less about having to wait a month for Warner's new releases to hit NetFlix. I want streaming content. NetFlix needs to realize the DVD model is DEAD and start making deals for more streaming content. If they could make new releases available within three months on their streaming service, they would seriously impact Blockbusters' brick and mortar business, forcing the studios to face facts.

I want choice in streaming content. Not titles like "Freezer Burn: The Invasion of Laxdale." You can only watch so many re-runs of Numb3rs. Where I live there is no cable service and I am not cutting down trees to get a satellite feed. So, my entertainment is books and NetFlix streaming. [Especially when I am snowed in, like now.] Screw the DVDs, give me more streaming!

The artificial market influences that Time Warner is trying to enforce just shows how shortsighted and how tightly they try to grasp to an increasingly outdated system. Not a big deal for Netflix since they do eventually want to phase out the physical mail portion of their business.

But somehow, this whole deal just goes to show that market desire is still not prioritized.

So, before this, Netflix would advertise the movie as being available, then it would sit on my queue for a month while I wait for a DVD to be available. Now, the movie will be released a month later, but because Netflix has more DVDs, I'll be able to get the movie immediately.

Meanwhile, I'll get more WB classics available for streaming. Sounds good to me.

Nick- Not to be picky, but isn't Android open source?  If so, it deserves equal mention w/Linux with regard to this attribute.  Apple has had a great run w/iPod and iPhone but their proprietary focus will ultimately marginalize the iPhone platform relative to Android in a manner similar to what happened w/PCs.  Verizon is on to something w/their iDon't campaign.  Many people may not care that they can't have a spare battery for their iPhone, but some component will.  Likewise with many other features.  The iPhone will likely fare better in phones and tablets- Google circa 2010 is no IBM circa 2004 and neither is MS when it comes to ultraportable devices- but ultimately, all the other phone and computer mfrs (not to mention the carriers) are going to start to coalesce around something and Android looks like the most likely  beneficiary.  Too bad for Palm.  Their platform is the best, but best tech doesn't mean much.

You mean the *free software* system GNU/Linux. "Open Source" was a term coined many years after "free software" by business interests, and it essentially means nothing. Free Software is software architected to concentrate on the freedoms available to a user to inspect, modify, improve, and share the software. If HP locks down the device so that only cryptographically signed images of underlying free software will run, then HP will be denying users the freedom they deserve. Many companies already play this gimmick -- most notably Tivo.

Demand your freedom in devices which run on Free Software!

Dear Netflix & Warner Bros;

I will be canceling my Netflix subscription and plan on watching fewer movies… instead of filling my queue with numerous movies that you have recommended to me I will be visiting your competitors and only watching movies that I had planned on watching.

Consequently, I will also be purchasing fewer movies as well; just movies I have already seen and know is worth owning.

Thank you for giving time back to my life; I will enjoy spending it away from the couch.
